newsitem.title: INDIA: INDIA CONGRESS CHIEF VOWS TO WIN ELECTIONS.
newsitem.headline: INDIA CONGRESS CHIEF VOWS TO WIN ELECTIONS.

text.p: Congress party president Sitaram Kesri pledged on Sunday to deliver victory at India's next general election and urged the party's workers to close ranks and strengthen the organisation.

Congress, which has ruled India for all but five of the 50 years since independence, finished a humiliating second in a general election last year but it provides make-or-break backing to Prime Minister Inder Kumar Gujral's 15-party coalition.
"You discipline yourselves, give me your support, I will give you power in Delhi," Kesri said in a closing address at the party's plenary session.

"You will give us the strength to march towards Delhi and unfurl the national flag at Red Fort." The historic Red Fort is the traditional venue where the nation's prime minister unfurls the national flag on Independence Day (August 15).
The Congress chief has repeatedly vowed during the three-day meeting to lead the party back into power.

Kesri said he did not want to grab power by dislodging the present government. "My eyes are on Delhi but not by removing this government but through people's mandate," he told Reuters after giving a general media briefing.
Kesri ignited a political crisis in March when he abruptly withdrew support for the then prime minister, H.D. Deve Gowda, who was later toppled in a parliamentary vote of confidence.
The centre-left United Front then turned to Gujral, who has since enjoyed Congress' support but has been undermined by tensions within his own party and coalition.

Kesri said the coalition government was unable to provide stability and fulfill the aspirations of the people. He predicted an early election but ruled it out in the immediate future. A government can remain in office for up to five years.
"I am ready and I have started my preparations. But I must also say elections are not going to come soon," he earlier told the briefing.
Kesri, who was re-elected as party president in June, promised to tour all the states with an eye on the polls.
He said Congress must be on its guard and fight the right-wing Hindu opposition Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) and left-wing parties.
"Be cautious aginst these forces. We have to fight against the BJP and the left," Kesri said.
BJP, the main opposition, is the single largest party in parliament.
Kesri rebutted allegations of corruption against Congress, saying the party never spared the corrupt. "Congress is more honest than other parties, cleaner than others."
The indictment of many party leaders in corruption scandals put paid to party's bid for power at the last general election.
More than half a dozen ministers of the 112-year-old Congress, once synonymous with the freedom movement, resigned after being charged in a money-laundering scandal.
Kesri appeared to have crossed a major hurdle on Saturday when seven of his supporters were leading in an election to the party's elite decision-making body, the Congress Working Committee (CWC).
The CWC has 20 members, of which 10 are elected and the rest nominated by the party chief.
